The most stable and common isotope is radon-222, born from the decay chain of uranium-238 with a half-life of about 3.8 days. It seeps from the ground—especially in granitic or volcanic regions—and can accumulate in enclosed spaces (houses, basements, mines). There it becomes a health hazard, because its radioactive progeny can be inhaled and contribute to lung cancer.

Because of its radioactivity, radon has no common industrial uses like neon or xenon. It was, however, used in the past in medicine, notably in early forms of radiotherapy thanks to its alpha emissions. Today that use has nearly vanished, replaced by better controlled and safer isotopes. Radon nevertheless remains a subject of study in geology (it can trace the presence of uranium) and in seismology, as changes in soil emissions have sometimes been correlated with tectonic activity.

Like the other noble gases, radon is largely inert. Under experimental conditions it can form a handful of rare compounds, such as radon difluoride (RnF₂). These molecules are extremely unstable and do not survive long because of radon’s radioactivity. In practice, it remains a monoatomic gas, elusive and fleeting.

A noble gas but not a harmless one, radon is both a witness to Earth’s radioactive processes and an invisible threat to human health. Its rarity and instability set it apart within its family, making it a darker element than its luminous cousins. Heir to the rocks and a subterranean traveler, it reminds us that noble gas chemistry does not always rhyme with inertia and safety.

details.summary: An alkali metal as rare as it is fleeting, francium is a radioactive element born from radium that vanishes within minutes.
paragraphs: Symbol "Fr", atomic number 87, francium is a highly radioactive alkali metal related to cesium and rubidium. Its existence is so fleeting that no macroscopic sample has ever been observed: everything we know comes from experiments on just a few atoms at a time. It would probably melt around 27 °C and would be liquid under slightly warm ambient conditions. Discovered in 1939 at the Curie laboratory by physicist Marguerite Perey, former assistant to Marie Curie, it was named francium in tribute to France—the last element discovered in nature and named for a country.

Francium forms only fleetingly in supernovae and in the natural fission reactions of thorium and uranium. It belongs to the decay chain of actinium: each atom of francium is born from radium and transforms into astatine or radon after just a few minutes. These isotopes are therefore ephemeral, part of a continuous cycle of birth and disappearance. In the universe, francium exists only as momentary traces in regions rich in radioactive elements.

On Earth, francium is one of the rarest elements: it is estimated that no more than 20 to 30 grams exist in the entire crust at any given time. It is produced naturally in uranium and thorium ores, where it results from the decay of radium-223. Its short half-life (22 minutes for the most stable isotope, ^223Fr) prevents any accumulation. Francium can therefore only be observed in the laboratory, produced artificially by bombarding thorium or radium with protons.

Francium has no industrial or medical applications, its rarity and radioactivity making any large-scale handling impossible. It is studied solely in atomic physics, notably to test models of relativistic electronic structure and the fundamental symmetries of the weak interaction. Experiments on a few thousand laser-trapped atoms have refined theoretical predictions about heavy alkali metals.

No stable compound of francium has ever been isolated. By analogy with its neighbors, scientists predict the existence of Fr⁺ ions and salts such as francium chloride (FrCl) or francium hydroxide (FrOH), even more basic than those of cesium. In practice these compounds survive only a few seconds before being destroyed by the radioactive decay of the metal itself.

Francium is a frontier element, on the edge of what nature can keep stable. Born from radium and destined to disappear almost immediately, it embodies the absolute fleetingness of matter. Discovered by a French scientist in the Curie lineage, it remains both a national and scientific symbol: an ephemeral atom that proves human ingenuity can detect, in a flash of decay, the trace of a metal that barely exists.

details.summary: An extremely radioactive alkaline earth metal, radium shines with historic brilliance between Curie discoveries and health hazards.
paragraphs: Symbol "Ra", atomic number 88, radium is a silvery-white alkaline earth metal that shines when freshly isolated but darkens in air because an oxide forms. It is highly radioactive and chemically close to barium and calcium. Discovered in 1898 by Pierre and Marie Curie from pitchblende (uraninite), it was isolated in metallic form in 1910 by Marie Curie and André Debierne. Its name comes from the Latin radius, "ray", in reference to the luminescence it emits spontaneously in the dark.

Radium is a transient product of the decay of uranium and thorium. In massive stars it forms during the rapid neutron-capture process (r-process), but it never lasts long: its isotopes quickly decay toward radon, francium, and lead. It thus belongs to the natural radioactive family of uranium-238, which ultimately ends in the stability of lead-206.

On Earth, radium is rare (about 1 part per 10¹² of uranium), present only as traces in uranium ores, especially pitchblende. At the end of the 19th century, the Curies processed several tons of ore to isolate a few milligrams of radium in a titanic effort. Today it is obtained by extracting uranium residues or by artificial production in nuclear reactors. Its most stable isotope, ^226Ra, has a half-life of 1,600 years.

Radium was first celebrated as a scientific wonder. Its spontaneous luminescence led to its use in phosphorescent paints for watches and military instruments in the early 20th century. It was also used in early radiotherapy treatments before being replaced by cobalt-60 and other, safer isotopes. Today radium no longer has common industrial uses: its extreme radioactivity and toxicity forced its abandonment. Nevertheless, it remains a reference element in radiophysics, and its historical study laid the foundations of modern nuclear medicine and dosimetry.

Radium compounds are analogous to those of barium: radium chloride (RaCl₂), bromide (RaBr₂), carbonate (RaCO₃), and sulfate (RaSO₄). All are highly radioactive and luminescent because of the metal’s decay. Radium spontaneously emits radon (^222Rn), a radioactive noble gas that accumulates in rocks and basements and is a natural source of exposure for humans.

Radium is a metal with a double face: it illuminated science as much as it burned those who approached it. Discovered by the Curies through superhuman efforts, it offered the world tangible proof of the power contained within matter. But it also reminded us of the cost of knowledge when fascination with its glow led to health disasters. Even today, radium embodies the dawn of radioactivity—the moment when human curiosity brought the energy of the stars to light.

details.summary: A rare, intensely radioactive actinide, actinium bridges stellar nucleosynthesis and the most targeted nuclear therapies.
paragraphs: Symbol "Ac", atomic number 89, actinium is a silvery to gray actinide metal discovered by André-Louis Debierne at the turn of the 20th century. Present only in trace amounts in Earth’s crust, it was among the first radioactive elements identified after uranium and thorium.

Cosmically, actinium is forged by neutron-capture processes in extreme stellar environments before being trapped in the primordial material of the Solar System. On Earth it occurs only in infinitesimal quantities within uranium and thorium ores, where it appears as an intermediate product in certain decay chains.

Its uses remain rare and tightly regulated. The isotope ^225Ac, with a half-life of about ten days, is studied as a source of targeted alpha therapy against certain cancers, while ^227Ac still serves occasionally as a neutron source or research material. Its intense radioactivity and scarcity rule out any routine industrial application.

Chemically, actinium almost exclusively adopts the +3 oxidation state in solution, mirroring trivalent lanthanides. Compounds such as Ac₂O₃, AcCl₃, or Ac(NO₃)₃ shed light on actinide chemistry and guide the separation and containment strategies required for radioactive waste management.

Actinium is therefore both a precious witness to stellar reactions and a cutting-edge research tool, yet its extreme radioactivity enforces stringent radiological protocols that confine its use to highly specialized contexts.

details.summary: A silvery-gray actinide with natural radioactivity, thorium blends stellar origins with the promise of thorium–uranium fuel cycles.
paragraphs: Symbol “Th” and atomic number 90, thorium is a silvery-gray, malleable, and ductile actinide metal. Its dominant isotope ^232Th has a half-life of about 14 billion years, giving it a diffuse yet persistent presence in Earth’s crust.

Cosmically it is forged by rapid neutron-capture (r-process) events such as supernovae or neutron-star mergers before mixing into the solar nebula. On Earth it has been present since planetary formation, concentrating in heavy minerals like monazite or thorite that supply industrial extraction.

Historically thorium was used in gas lamp mantles, high-index optical glasses, and certain alloys or welding electrodes. Today its main appeal lies in the thorium–uranium-233 fuel cycle, explored for safer and more abundant nuclear reactors, although commercialization remains limited and tightly regulated.

Chemically thorium favors the +4 oxidation state in solution and forms compounds such as ThO₂, Th(NO₃)₄, and ThCl₄. Thorium dioxide is notable for its extremely high melting point and stability, underpinning past refractory and optical applications.

As both an ancient and contemporary actinide, thorium requires handling protocols tailored to its radioactivity. Its fertile energy potential continues to drive research into alternative nuclear fuels at the crossroads of cosmic heritage and modern innovation.

details.summary: A dense, highly radioactive actinide, protactinium is a research element that emerges as a transient product of uranium decay chains.
paragraphs: Symbol “Pa” and atomic number 91, protactinium is a silvery-gray actinide metal whose most abundant natural isotope, ^231Pa, has a half-life of roughly 32,760 years.

It originates in rapid neutron-capture events in stellar environments before becoming trapped in the primordial Solar System material. Within Earth’s crust it arises mainly from uranium and thorium decay chains, persisting only at ppt-to-ppm levels in ores such as monazite or uraninite.

Because of its scarcity, toxicity, and radioactivity, protactinium has virtually no industrial uses. It is studied in nuclear research as a tracer and as an intermediate in thorium–uranium fuel cycles, and it is isolated only in tiny amounts from irradiated nuclear fuel.

Its chemistry is dominated by the +5 oxidation state, although +4, +3, and +2 states appear under specific conditions. Laboratory-characterized compounds include Pa₂O₅, PaO₂, and various halides and nitrates, all requiring shielded, glovebox handling.

A rare yet scientifically valuable element, protactinium illuminates natural decay series and certain dating techniques, but strict radiological controls confine its use to specialized research contexts.

details.summary: A heavy, naturally radioactive metal, uranium powers nuclear energy while demanding stringent safety and waste controls.
paragraphs: Symbol “U”, atomic number 92, uranium is a dense, heavy metal with a slightly metallic luster and intrinsic radioactivity. In nature it occurs mainly as oxides and ores such as uraninite or carnotite, and its dominant isotopes ^238U and ^235U have half-lives of 4.47×10^9 and 7.04×10^8 years respectively, making it a long-lived geological tracer.

Cosmically, uranium is forged through rapid neutron-capture (r-process) events in extreme stellar environments—supernovae or neutron-star mergers—before being incorporated into the nebula that formed the Solar System. On Earth it has been present since the planet’s birth, averaging about 2.8 ppm in the crust, with exploitable deposits surveyed and monitored by international agencies.

Its most prominent use is energetic: after concentration and enrichment to raise the ^235U fraction, uranium fuels the vast majority of commercial nuclear reactors. It also enters nuclear weapons, certain armor and penetrators made of depleted uranium, and the irradiation chains that produce medical or industrial isotopes.

Chemically, uranium is a reactive metal that commonly adopts U⁴⁺ and UO₂²⁺ (uranyl) states. It appears as uranium dioxide UO₂—the standard fuel form—as well as other oxides, nitrates, and fluorides; hexafluoride UF₆ is the gaseous form used for enrichment. Its behavior strongly depends on pH and redox potential, parameters central to waste management and mine-site remediation.

A dual-nature element, uranium is simultaneously a major energy resource and a source of radiological, environmental, and geopolitical risk that requires robust safeguards. Known reserves are sufficient for current and projected reactor fleets, yet economic viability and safety remain ongoing technical and political challenges.

Synthetic timeline: 1789 – Klaproth identifies the oxide of a new element; 1896 – Becquerel discovers radioactivity in uranium salts; 1938–1939 – Hahn, Strassmann, Meitner, and Frisch reveal fission; 1942 – Chicago Pile-1 achieves the first self-sustained chain reaction; 1945 – the Little Boy bomb uses highly enriched uranium; 1954–1956 – Obninsk then Calder Hall inaugurate commercial nuclear power; since then uranium has sat at the heart of debates on energy, security, and waste.

Fuel cycle: mining of ores (uraninite, carnotite, monazite, etc.) → crushing and milling to produce yellowcake (U₃O₈) → conversion to UF₆ for transport and enrichment → enrichment (3–5% ^235U for reactors, >85% for weapons) → fabrication of UO₂ pellets and fuel assemblies → reactor irradiation producing energy and transuranics → interim storage in pools then dry casks → optional PUREX reprocessing → conditioning and final disposal of high-level waste.

Technical, health, and geopolitical challenges: safety and radioprotection during handling, transport, and storage; proliferation risks tied to the same enrichment technologies; economics governed by ore prices, enrichment costs, and technology choices; long-term waste management and public acceptance; alternative pathways under study (closed fuel cycles, fast breeders, thorium cycles) that remain difficult to deploy.

Key figures: typical civilian fuel enrichment 3–5% ^235U, weapons-grade >85–90%; key half-lives ^238U ≈ 4.47×10^9 years and ^235U ≈ 7.04×10^8 years; UF₆—uranium hexafluoride—is the indispensable yet corrosive gaseous form used for enrichment.

details.summary: A silvery, radioactive transuranium metal, neptunium bridges uranium chemistry and the birth of plutonium in the nuclear cycle.
paragraphs: Symbol “Np”, atomic number 93, neptunium is a dense, radioactive metal with modest malleability. The first transuranium element ever identified, it was discovered in 1940 at Berkeley by Edwin McMillan and Philip Abelson, and its most stable isotope ^237Np has a half-life of about 2.14 million years.

Cosmically, neptunium can form through neutron captures in stellar environments, but its short half-lives prevent any primordial accumulation from surviving since the Solar System formed. On Earth it is chiefly artificial, produced by irradiating uranium in reactors via the chain ^238U(n,γ)^239U → ^239Np → ^239Pu; only trace natural occurrences have been detected in certain ores.

Neptunium has no mass-market industrial application, yet it plays a significant scientific role. It serves as a reference material for radioprotection and actinide chemistry studies, as a precursor to plutonium-238 used in space probe radioisotope generators, and as a subject in research on fast reactors and nuclear fuel recycling.

Chemically, neptunium adopts multiple oxidation states from +3 to +7. It forms oxides such as NpO₂, halides like NpF₆ and NpCl₄, and complexes analogous to those of uranium and plutonium. Investigating these species in solution helps elucidate the mobility and confinement of heavy actinides within the fuel cycle and the environment.

As the first link in the transuranium series, neptunium illuminates the transition between source uranium and the plutonium it begets. Scarce in nature but indispensable to nuclear science, it encapsulates the challenges of controlling and recycling the heaviest radioactive materials.

details.summary: A dense, highly radioactive actinide, plutonium embodies global challenges across energy, military strategy, and safety.
paragraphs: Symbol "Pu", atomic number 94, plutonium is a dense actinide metal that appears silvery when metallic but is commonly handled as oxides. Its headline isotopes, ^239Pu (half-life ≈ 24,110 years) and ^238Pu (half-life ≈ 87.7 years), showcase intense radioactivity and physico-chemical properties that shift with oxidation state.

Discovered and isolated in the early 1940s by the teams led by Glenn Seaborg and Edwin McMillan, plutonium occurs only in trace natural amounts. It is chiefly manufactured in nuclear reactors through neutron capture on ^238U, following the chain ^238U → ^239U → ^239Np → ^239Pu, although rare geological events or historic atmospheric tests have yielded minute traces.

Its uses are sharply contrasted: ^239Pu is a fissile isotope central to nuclear weapons, certain reactors, and MOX fuel, whereas ^238Pu powers radioisotope thermoelectric generators for space exploration and any system requiring long-lived autonomy. Plutonium also sits at the heart of research into fuel cycles, reprocessing, and transmutation under stringent safety and non-proliferation frameworks.

Chemically, plutonium spans several oxidation states (primarily +3 to +6) and forms a wide range of compounds: plutonium dioxide PuO₂ — the stable form for fuel and storage — halides, nitrates, and solution complexes. Its redox chemistry governs solubility, environmental mobility, and waste management, while the alpha-emitting isotopes’ radiotoxicity demands strict exposure controls.

Strategic yet problematic, plutonium concentrates immense energetic and destructive potential alongside major safety, waste-management, and diplomatic challenges. Its production, use, and confinement are bound by rigorous international regulations to contain technical, health, and political risks.

details.summary: A synthetic, silvery, radioactive actinide, americium combines targeted applications with stringent radioprotection demands.
paragraphs: Symbol "Am", atomic number 95, americium is a synthetic actinide that appears silvery when reduced to metal. Dominant isotopes ^241Am (half-life ≈ 432 years) and ^243Am (half-life ≈ 7,370 years) make it a highly radioactive element that is scarce in nature yet plentiful as a reactor by-product.

Discovered in 1944 by Glenn Seaborg’s team and named after the American continent, americium arises mainly through successive neutron captures on plutonium and other actinides inside reactors. Only minute traces may appear in certain radioactive deposits, leaving its production almost entirely anthropogenic.

Despite its radiotoxicity, ^241Am underpins real-world uses: ionizing sources within smoke detectors, ^241Am–Be neutron sources for calibration, industrial prospecting, and geophysics, along with roles in actinide chemistry and nuclear physics research. Every application nevertheless demands strict radioprotection and confinement protocols.

Chemically, americium favors the +3 oxidation state in solution, forming compounds such as Am₂O₃, AmO₂, nitrates, and halides. Its chemistry, akin to that of lanthanides and other trivalent actinides, is pivotal for actinide separation and nuclear waste management studies, while organometallic complexes largely remain within research laboratories.

A typically anthropogenic element, americium enables specialized instruments yet requires rigorous health safeguards against inhalation or ingestion risks. It exemplifies how nuclear science turns a radioactive by-product into a useful but tightly confined resource.

details.summary: A dense, highly radioactive synthetic actinide, curium honors the Curies while serving as both an energy source and a research tool.
paragraphs: Discovered in 1944 by Glenn Seaborg, Ralph James, and Albert Ghiorso at the University of California, Berkeley, curium (symbol Cm, atomic number 96) is a silvery, dense actinide metal harder than americium, with notable isotopes such as ^242Cm, ^244Cm, and ^248Cm that span very different half-lives.

Absent from Earth's crust, curium is produced artificially in nuclear reactors through successive neutron captures on plutonium and americium followed by beta decays, with only trace amounts arising in nuclear explosions or dedicated research experiments.

Its uses are highly specialized: ^244Cm and ^242Cm have powered early radioisotope thermoelectric generators for NASA probes, and its alpha and neutron emissions make it valuable in laboratories, even though intense radioactivity and self-heating prevent industrial-scale applications.

Chemically, curium most often adopts the +3 oxidation state, forming oxides, halides, nitrates, and aqueous complexes that help scientists understand nuclear fuel cycles and waste separation, while rarer +4 and +6 states appear only under specific conditions.

As a key milestone among synthetic actinides, curium embodies both the promise and the challenges of modern nuclear chemistry, simultaneously an energy resource, a research subject, and a long-lived waste product.

details.summary: A rare artificial actinide, berkelium is prized as a scientific stepping stone toward heavier elements and for probing actinide chemistry.
paragraphs: Identified in 1949 by Glenn T. Seaborg's team at the University of California, Berkeley, berkelium (symbol Bk, atomic number 97) is a radioactive, silvery, malleable actinide metal that reacts readily with air, and its most stable isotope, ^247Bk, has a half-life of about 1,380 years.

Entirely synthetic, it is produced in high-flux reactors by successive neutron captures on curium or americium followed by beta decays, with only minuscule quantities formed in nuclear explosions or transmutation experiments, leaving no naturally occurring isotopes on Earth.

Its applications are chiefly scientific: as a precursor to californium, a valuable neutron source, berkelium-249 has enabled the synthesis of superheavy elements such as tennessine, while scarcity and radioactivity keep it out of everyday industrial use.
Chemically it favors the +3 oxidation state, forming oxides like Bk₂O₃, halides such as BkCl₃ or BkF₃, and aqueous complexes whose lanthanide-like behavior refines actinide separation techniques.

Produced in only a few specialized laboratories, berkelium remains a crucial scientific tool for creating heavier elements and exploring actinide behavior at the boundary between experimental chemistry and modern nuclear physics.

details.summary: Californium is an ultra-rare synthetic actinide prized as a compact neutron source despite its high cost and radiological hazards.
paragraphs: Overview — Symbol "Cf", atomic number 98, californium is a synthetic transuranic actinide. When prepared in bulk it is a silvery metal, highly radioactive, and exists only through human production in extremely limited quantities. Several isotopes are known; among them ^252Cf is the isotope most used industrially, while ^251Cf is the most stable known (half-life ≈ 898 years).

Origins (cosmic & terrestrial) — Cosmically, californium arises from the same heavy nucleosynthesis (r-process) as other heavy elements, but it does not persist naturally because most of its isotopes are short-lived. On Earth it is entirely produced by prolonged neutron irradiation of actinides (curium, berkelium, etc.) in high-flux reactors or synthesized in accelerators; it was first created at Berkeley in 1950. Commercial production remains very limited and concentrated (e.g., Oak Ridge, USA and RIAR, Russia).

Uses — The most exploited property is the neutron emission of ^252Cf (a very high neutron flux per microgram). This makes the isotope valuable as a portable neutron source for neutron radiography, neutron activation (elemental analysis), ore and hydrocarbon detection, reactor start-up, and a few specialized medical applications. Limited production and high costs restrict its use to situations where no practical alternative exists.

Chemistry & associated compounds — Chemically, californium behaves like the other heavy actinides: it preferentially adopts the +3 oxidation state in solution and forms oxides (Cf₂O₃), halides, and nitrates in the laboratory. Its chemistry is mostly studied on microgram scales to understand actinide behavior and to optimize their separation or recycling; handling requires specialized radiological facilities.

Conclusion — Californium is a niche material of very high scientific and technological value: produced in tiny amounts, it serves as an indispensable neutron source in several industrial and scientific domains. Its cost, radioactivity, and scarce production make it a strategic element under strict regulation.

details.summary: Born from nuclear explosions, einsteinium is a synthetic actinide reserved for fundamental research on heavy actinides and superheavy elements.
paragraphs: Overview — Symbol "Es", atomic number 99, einsteinium is a radioactive, silvery actinide metal produced artificially in very small quantities. Discovered in 1952 in the fallout of the first American thermonuclear explosion (Ivy Mike), it was first identified in the debris of the hydrogen bomb. The most stable known isotope is ^252Es, with a half-life of about 471 days.

Origins — Einsteinium does not occur naturally on Earth; it is entirely synthetic. It forms in nuclear explosions or in reactors with extremely high neutron fluxes by irradiating curium or plutonium followed by several neutron captures and beta decays. Its discovery was kept secret for several years because of its military origin.

Uses — Applications of einsteinium are essentially scientific. Its intense radioactivity and minuscule production (a few micrograms at most) restrict it to research on heavy actinides and the synthesis of superheavy elements: einsteinium was notably used to produce mendelevium (Md, 101). Outside these contexts of fundamental nuclear research, it has no industrial use.

Chemistry & associated compounds — Einsteinium mainly adopts the +3 oxidation state in solution, forming oxides (Es₂O₃), halides, and complexes similar to those of its neighbors curium and californium. Because of its strong alpha emission it self-heats at room temperature, complicating handling: even a few micrograms must be manipulated in radioprotected and thermally controlled environments.

Conclusion — Einsteinium is a symbol of twentieth-century nuclear science: born in the fire of a thermonuclear explosion, named in honor of Albert Einstein, and used to create other elements beyond the periodic table. Invisible in everyday life, it embodies the boundary between atomic physics and the creation of new forms of matter.

details.summary: A synthetic actinide born from the Ivy Mike thermonuclear test, fermium honors Enrico Fermi and exists only as highly radioactive isotopes.
paragraphs: With symbol Fm and atomic number 100, fermium is a radioactive actinide metal discovered in 1952 in the fallout of the Ivy Mike thermonuclear explosion alongside einsteinium, and named for Enrico Fermi; its most stable isotope, ^257Fm, has a half-life of about 100 days.
It appears only when nuclear explosions or prolonged neutron irradiation of curium or plutonium in high-flux reactors trigger successive neutron captures and beta decays along the actinide series.
Like einsteinium, it has no industrial or medical use: only minute quantities are produced, serving primarily fundamental research on heavy actinides and the synthesis of trans-fermium elements.
Its chemistry is dominated by the +3 oxidation state, forming compounds such as Fm₂O₃ or FmCl₃; intense radioactivity heats even tiny samples and makes handling difficult.
Born in extreme conditions and absent from nature, fermium embodies pure scientific curiosity by extending humanity’s grasp of matter beyond what Earth provides.

details.summary: Created atom by atom in 1955 at Berkeley, mendelevium honors Dmitri Mendeleev and survives only as fleeting radioactive traces.
paragraphs: With symbol Md and atomic number 101, mendelevium is a radioactive actinide metal discovered in 1955 at the University of California, Berkeley by Albert Ghiorso’s team with Glenn Seaborg, and named for Dmitri Mendeleev; its most stable isotope, ^258Md, has a half-life of about 51 days.

This purely artificial element is produced by bombarding einsteinium-253 with helium ions (^4He) in a particle accelerator, a milestone experiment that created a new element atom by atom and tracked each decay.
Its applications are confined to research: manufactured in millionths of a gram, mendelevium helps study nuclear stability and the chemistry of extreme actinides on the path to superheavy elements.

Its chemistry is dominated by the +3 oxidation state, though +2 states have been observed, hinting at lanthanide-like behavior; compounds such as MdCl₃ or Md₂O₃ are known only at infinitesimal scales.
As a nod to the architect of the periodic table, mendelevium symbolizes the blend of prediction and discovery at the heart of modern atomic exploration.

details.summary: An artificial transuranic actinide honoring Alfred Nobel, nobelium exists only as highly radioactive atoms created in laboratories.
paragraphs: Overview — Nobelium (symbol No, atomic number 102) is an artificial transuranic actinide officially recognized in 1966 and named after Alfred Nobel; all known isotopes are unstable with half-lives ranging from milliseconds to a few hours.

Origins — Nobelium has no natural occurrence: it is produced in laboratories through fusion reactions (bombarding heavy targets with light ions) or by irradiation in very high-flux reactors, yielding only vanishing amounts of matter—mere atoms or nanograms.

Properties and uses — Nobelium has no industrial or technological applications; its limited production and intense radioactivity confine it to research, where experiments focus on measuring nuclear properties and a handful of chemical behaviors at extremely small scales.

Chemistry and associated compounds — The scarce chemical studies point to behavior similar to other heavy actinides with a dominant +3 oxidation state in solution; only simple compounds such as halides or oxides have been investigated experimentally, without any usable quantities.

Conclusion — Nobelium remains a laboratory element, another milestone in exploring actinides and nuclear structure: a historical nod to Alfred Nobel whose value today is purely scientific within specialized facilities.

details.summary: The last actinide, lawrencium is an artificial transuranic element named for Ernest O. Lawrence and produced only in infinitesimal amounts.
paragraphs: Overview — Lawrencium (symbol Lr, atomic number 103) is a radioactive artificial transuranic element and the final official member of the actinide series; in metallic form it would appear silvery, yet it is observed only atom by atom or at nanoscopic scales in laboratories.

Origins — First synthesized in the early 1960s at Berkeley and named in honor of cyclotron inventor Ernest O. Lawrence, lawrencium does not exist naturally; it is created by fusing light ions with heavy targets in accelerators or by intense irradiation of actinides in specialized reactors, yielding just a few atoms to a few nanograms.

Uses — Lawrencium has no industrial role and serves purely as a research tool to probe the chemistry and physics of superheavy elements, test theoretical predictions on electronic structure and relativistic effects, and refine detection and analysis methods in nuclear science.

Chemistry and associated compounds — Its chemistry remains largely unexplored because of extreme scarcity and short-lived isotopes; nonetheless, it is expected to favor a +3 oxidation state in solution like most actinides, while relativistic effects on its outer electrons make it fundamentally intriguing.

Conclusion — As a symbolic milestone of the periodic table dedicated to an accelerator pioneer, lawrencium marks the boundary between classical chemistry and the study of nuclei and electrons under extreme conditions, with each synthesized atom revealing a little more about matter.

details.summary: A fully artificial superheavy element, rutherfordium pushes transition-metal chemistry to the frontiers of nuclear physics.
paragraphs: Symbol "Rf" and atomic number 104, rutherfordium is a superheavy element confirmed in 1997 and named in honor of physicist Ernest Rutherford, a pioneer of nuclear science.

It does not occur naturally: every atom is produced in the laboratory by colliding heavy nuclei. Its isotopes survive only a few seconds to several minutes at best, granting just enough time for chemical and spectrometric experiments.

Belonging to the group of titanium and zirconium, rutherfordium behaves like a typical transition metal according to experiments carried out on mere atoms. Its blistering radioactivity and minuscule production keep it exclusively within the realm of fundamental research.

As the first representative of the superheavy element series, it links the familiar chemistry of transition metals with the exploration of relativistic effects governing the most massive nuclei, illustrating the continuum between the foundations of atomic science and the quest for its extreme limits.

details.summary: A synthetic superheavy element confirmed in 1997, dubnium honors the Russian science city of Dubna where its discovery was achieved.
paragraphs: Dubnium, symbol "Db" and atomic number 105, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1997. It takes its name from the science city of Dubna in Russia, home to the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research, a major contributor to its discovery.
It is a synthetic element produced by bombarding heavy nuclei in a particle accelerator. Its isotopes decay within seconds at most, preventing any lasting natural presence.

Dubnium belongs to the family of transition metals in the group of tantalum and niobium. Limited chemical studies have confirmed this behavior. No practical use is possible because of its radioactivity and scarcity.

Dubnium marks an important milestone in international research on heavy elements. Its name honors a key scientific center in the synthesis of superheavy elements, symbolizing collaboration between laboratories worldwide.

details.summary: Confirmed in 1993, seaborgium honors chemist Glenn T. Seaborg and briefly extends transition-metal chemistry beyond uranium.
paragraphs: Seaborgium, symbol "Sg" and atomic number 106, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1993. It pays tribute to American chemist Glenn T. Seaborg, one of the discoverers of many transuranium elements.
It is an artificial element obtained by nuclear fusion of heavy nuclei. All its isotopes are unstable, with half-lives ranging from a few milliseconds to about a minute for the most durable.

Seaborgium belongs to the group of tungsten and molybdenum. A handful of chemical experiments have confirmed that it shares some of their properties, behaving like a typical transition metal. Its rarity and radioactivity confine it to pure research.

Seaborgium is one of the few superheavy elements whose chemistry has been briefly observed. Fleeting yet instructive, it bears the name of a researcher who profoundly shaped the history of the periodic table.

details.summary: A fully synthetic superheavy element, bohrium honors Niels Bohr and remains a fleeting subject of laboratory study.
paragraphs: Bohrium, symbol "Bh" and atomic number 107, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1981. It was named in honor of Danish physicist Niels Bohr, a major figure in atomic physics.

It is an artificial element created in particle accelerators by fusing heavy nuclei. Its isotopes have very short half-lives, on the order of a second or less, which means it does not occur naturally.

Bohrium belongs to the manganese group, and simulations indicate it may behave like a typical transition metal. However, its radioactivity prevents any in-depth chemical study and no practical use arises from it.

Bohrium illustrates the methodical pursuit of research on superheavy elements. Bearing the name of a pioneer of atomic physics, it symbolically links the foundations of quantum theory to today’s exploration of matter.

details.summary: An artificial superheavy element discovered in Hesse, hassium exists only in laboratories despite properties consistent with its periodic-table group.
paragraphs: Hassium, symbol "Hs" and atomic number 108, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1984. It takes its name from the German state of Hesse, where it was synthesized for the first time.
It is artificial, produced in particle accelerators by fusing heavy nuclei. Its isotopes have half-lives ranging from milliseconds to a few minutes for the most stable ones.

Hassium belongs to the group of iron metals (group 8). Limited experiments suggest it indeed behaves like a transition metal and can form volatile oxides. Nonetheless, it remains out of reach for any practical application.

Hassium confirms that even superheavy elements can sometimes display chemical properties consistent with their position in the table. Ephemeral, it remains above all a subject of scientific study and a milestone in the exploration of the ultimate elements.

details.summary: A superheavy synthetic element discovered in 1982, meitnerium honors physicist Lise Meitner.
paragraphs: Meitnerium, symbol Mt and atomic number 109, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1982. It was named in honor of physicist Lise Meitner, co-discoverer of nuclear fission.
It is a synthetic element produced by bombarding heavy nuclei in a particle accelerator. The isotopes observed so far decay within milliseconds, ruling out any natural occurrence.

Classified alongside cobalt and iridium, it is expected to be a dense, heavy transition metal. Its lifetime is too short for direct chemical studies, leaving it with no practical applications and value only for science.
Meitnerium stands as a tribute to a major figure in nuclear physics and a new milestone in the periodic table. Fleeting and inaccessible, it marks humanity’s progress in probing the limits of matter.

details.summary: Discovered in 1994, the superheavy element darmstadtium bears the name of the German city where it was created.
paragraphs: Darmstadtium, symbol Ds and atomic number 110, is a superheavy element confirmed in 1994. It was named after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered at the GSI Helmholtz Centre for Heavy Ion Research.
It is an artificial element produced in the laboratory by fusing heavy nuclei. Its known isotopes are extremely unstable, with half-lives ranging from milliseconds to about a second.

Classed among the transition metals of the nickel and platinum group, it may share some of their properties, but its very short lifetime prevents any experimental chemistry. It has no use beyond fundamental research.

Darmstadtium is a short-lived element that showcases the achievements of modern nuclear physics. Its name recalls the site of its discovery, highlighting Darmstadt’s role in exploring the frontiers of the periodic table.

details.summary: A synthetic superheavy element named for Wilhelm Röntgen, roentgenium survives only milliseconds in the lab.
paragraphs: Discovered in 2004, roentgenium (Rg, atomic number 111) is a superheavy element named in honor of Wilhelm Röntgen, the physicist who revealed X-rays to the scientific world.
Entirely synthetic, it is produced by bombarding heavy nuclei in particle accelerators. The isotopes created decay within a few milliseconds, which explains its total absence in nature.
Roentgenium sits in the same column as gold and silver in the periodic table, hinting at similar metallic properties, but its vanishingly short lifetime prevents any chemical study or practical use.
A pure laboratory product, it chiefly symbolizes the current limits of nuclear synthesis and keeps Röntgen’s legacy alive rather than serving as an exploitable resource.

details.summary: Copernicium is a superheavy element dedicated to Nicolaus Copernicus that exists only fleetingly in the particle accelerators that create it.
paragraphs: Officially recognized in 2009, copernicium (Cn, atomic number 112) pays tribute to astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus and the cosmological revolution he set in motion.
It is produced artificially by fusing heavy nuclei inside particle accelerators. Even its most stable isotopes last only a few minutes, far too short a time for it to arise naturally.
Classed alongside mercury, it might share certain metallic properties, yet its extreme rarity and radioactivity prevent direct observation of its chemistry or any practical application.
As an experimental milestone on the periodic table, copernicium serves primarily as a scientific marker and echoes how discoveries reshape our understanding of the universe.

details.summary: Nihonium is a synthetic superheavy element discovered by a Japanese team—the first element found in Asia—and it exists only for a fleeting moment.
paragraphs: Nihonium, symbol Nh and atomic number 113, is a superheavy element officially recognized in 2016. Its name comes from Nihon, the Japanese word for “Japan,” honoring the RIKEN researchers who first identified it.

It is an artificial element produced by bombarding bismuth with zinc nuclei in a particle accelerator. Its known isotopes have half-lives ranging from milliseconds to a few seconds, far too brief for it to occur naturally.

Classified alongside thallium in the periodic table, it could theoretically share some heavy-metal properties, but no direct chemical experiment has yet been conclusive. It has no practical use—its value is purely scientific.

Nihonium is the first element discovered in Asia, and its name reflects that origin. Even though it exists only for an instant, it marks an important milestone in exploring superheavy elements and expanding the periodic table through global collaboration.

details.summary: Flerovium is a synthetic superheavy element named after the Flerov Laboratory, offering key insights into nuclear stability at the limits of the periodic table.
paragraphs: Flerovium, symbol Fl and atomic number 114, is a superheavy element officially recognized in 2012. It is named for the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions, honoring physicist Georgy Flerov, a pioneer of nuclear physics research.

Like other elements in its category, it is synthetic, created by colliding heavy nuclei in particle accelerators. Its known isotopes have half-lives of only a few seconds at most, making it one of the “longest-lived” superheavy elements while still preventing reliable direct chemical experiments.

It is classified with carbon and lead in the periodic table, but its actual chemistry remains hypothetical because of its instability. There are no practical uses; each synthesis of flerovium primarily yields data about the limits of nuclear stability and the structure of superheavy elements.

Flerovium is a milestone on the periodic table—fleeting yet essential for understanding the boundaries of matter. Its name and existence highlight the decisive contribution of Russian nuclear research to exploring the ultimate elements.

details.summary: Synthetic superheavy element 115 named in honor of the Moscow region.
paragraphs: Moscovium, symbol Mc and atomic number 115, is a superheavy element of the periodic table. It was officially recognized in 2016 and takes its name from the Moscow region, honoring the Russian laboratories involved in its discovery.

It is a synthetic element produced in laboratories by nuclear fusion of heavy nuclei. The observed isotopes have very short half-lives, generally below half a second, preventing any lasting natural presence.

Classed within the pnictogen family (like nitrogen and bismuth), it could theoretically share some of their properties. However, its brief existence keeps chemists from studying it in practice, leaving it without practical uses and of purely scientific interest.

Moscovium embodies the quest for superheavy elements: a fragment of matter that exists only for an instant, long enough to confirm its reality but too short to explore it. It marks another step in charting the frontiers of the periodic table.

details.summary: Synthetic superheavy element 116 dedicated to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
paragraphs: Livermorium, symbol Lv and atomic number 116, is a superheavy element of the periodic table. Its name honors the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (United States), which helped confirm its discovery in 2011.

Livermorium is an artificial element produced in laboratories by nuclear collisions between heavy nuclei. Its known isotopes have half-lives on the order of a second or less, making it inaccessible outside nuclear physics experiments.

In theory it belongs to the chalcogen family (like oxygen and sulfur), but its instability prevents any direct chemical study. No practical use exists: its value is purely scientific, tied to exploring the limits of nuclear stability.

Ephemeral and elusive, livermorium survives only moments after its creation. Rather than a usable substance, it stands as an outpost of the periodic table, testifying to humanity’s curiosity to push the boundaries of matter.

details.summary: Element 117, symbol Ts, is a superheavy halogen created only in laboratories since its 2010 discovery.
paragraphs: Synthesized in 2010 by a Russian–American collaboration, it honors the state of Tennessee and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory while remaining an extremely unstable, short-lived element.
Tennessine does not occur naturally: it is far too unstable to persist in the cosmos and is created by bombarding berkelium-249 with calcium-48 ions.
On Earth only a handful of atoms have been produced in nuclear accelerators, with the observed isotopes (^293Ts and ^294Ts) decaying in under a second via alpha emission.
It has no practical uses; instead, tennessine helps probe the limits of nuclear stability and the structure of the periodic table in the hunt for the theorized “island of stability”.
No compounds have been observed yet, but models predict unusual halogen chemistry, potentially less reactive and more “metallic” because of its mass and relativistic effects.
Ephemeral and human-made, tennessine stands as a scientific milestone marking how far physicists can push the periodic table.

details.summary: Element 118, symbol Og, is an ultraheavy noble gas whose fleeting existence has only been confirmed in the laboratory.
paragraphs: Discovered between 2002 and 2006 by a Russian–American team, it honors physicist Yuri Oganessian and is remarkable for its extreme instability.
Absent from the observable universe, oganesson decays in less than a millisecond and is produced by bombarding californium-249 with calcium-48 ions.
No terrestrial deposit contains it; only a few atoms synthesized in specialized facilities attest to its presence before they vanish.
With no practical applications, oganesson serves researchers probing the limits of nuclear stability and testing the proposed “island of stability”.
No compounds have been detected, yet theoretical calculations suggest richer-than-expected noble-gas chemistry, possibly including molecules such as OgF₂.
As the current edge of the periodic table, oganesson shows that matter still holds unexplored territories for nuclear physics experiments.
